review.title: Contextually Supervised Source Separation with Application to Energy Disaggregation
review.abstract: We propose a new framework for single-channel source separation that lies between the fully supervised and unsupervised setting. Instead of supervision, we provide input features for each source signal and use convex methods to estimate the correlations between these features and the unobserved signal decomposition. We analyze the case of $\ell_2$ loss theoretically and show that recovery of the signal components depends only on cross-correlation between features for different signals, not on correlations between features for the same signal. Contextually supervised source separation is a natural fit for domains with large amounts of data but no explicit supervision; our motivating application is energy disaggregation of hourly smart meter data (the separation of whole-home power signals into different energy uses). Here we apply contextual supervision to disaggregate the energy usage of thousands homes over four years, a significantly larger scale than previously published efforts, and demonstrate on synthetic data that our method outperforms the unsupervised approach.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We look at the single-channel source problem in two ways: the monitored setting [11, 17, 18], in which we have access to the training data, and the unattended (or "blind") setting [3, 6, 13, 19], in which we only have the overall signal. However, both settings have potential disadvantages: for many problems, including energy splitting - which separates individual energy consumers from an entire house [9] - it can be difficult to obtain training data with the true separate signals required for the monitored setting. In contrast, unattended setting is a problem with arbitrarily many solutions and associated algorithms.

sections.text: As mentioned above, the work in the single channel source is separation along the lines of monitored and unmonitored algorithms, although several algorithms can be applied on both sides. A common strategy is to transform the observed total signal into a linear combination of several bases, all falling into this category, with the differences between the bases and the different signal components becoming evident.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental results
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the contextual monitoring of each signal as highly correlated with each other, but we are not highly inconsistent in terms of the results of thousands of households. As the data is not available, we design a synthetic discretion that is similar to the energy disgregation of smart meters to quantify our performance. Here, we examine the choice of loss functions and show that the contextual monitoring dramatically exceeds the problem of separating two source signals, while starting with a series of experiments that restore the model's ability to restore the underlying source signals as predicted by our theoretical analysis. In these experiments, we look at the problem of separating two source signals with Xi-RT-16 sampled by a zero-mean normality with covariance I + (1 − µ) 11T; we sample the underlying source signals as they are predicted.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and discussion
sections.text: We believe that advances in this work, context-based source sharing monitoring and theoretical analysis of the requirements for accurate source signal recovery, will enable new applications of single-channel source sharing in areas with large amounts of data but without access to explicit monitoring. In energy breakdown, this approach has allowed us to reasonably identify consumption sources from extremely low frequency smart meter data, which is a significant advance with the potential to increase energy efficiency through programs that provide this information to consumers and automated demand response systems. Developing algorithms that use this information to achieve these goals is an interesting direction for future work.Another interesting direction is the explicit linking of our large-scale low-resolution methods with the more complex application models developed on smaller monitored datasets with high-frequency measurements.
